I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Turkmenistan for the North–South Railway Project.1  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
2.  Strategic context. The Government of Turkmenistan signed a multilateral agreement 
with its neighboring countries in October 2007 to construct a north–south railway line to promote 
regional trade, cooperation, and integration. This will be the region’s main route for transporting 
bulk goods, such as oil and oil products, minerals, agricultural products, and textiles. The 
planned  934.5-kilometer  (km)  railway  line2 (single  track  with  diesel  traction)  will  connect 
Turkmenistan with its neighboring countries to the north and south. Under Islamic Development 
Bank  (IDB)  assistance,  338.5  km  of  railway  track  south  from  Bereket  is  being  laid.  The 
government is financing the laying of 466.0 km of track for the northern section of the line (from 
Bereket to the Kazakhstan border). Both sections are scheduled to be completed in 2011. The 
Government  has  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  financing  for  the  design, 
procurement, and installation of the power supply, as well as signaling and telecommunication 
systems, for 311 km of the completed northern railway section between Bereket and Buzkhun. 
Procurement and installation of the power supply and signaling and telecommunication systems 
for the southern part is included in the IDB-assisted project; for the remaining northern section, it 
is planned through Government financing. 
 
3.  The north–south railway line will improve Turkmenistan's accessibility to Kazakhstan, the 
Persian Gulf countries, the Russian Federation, and South Asia. It will also increase regional 
trade. The project will contribute to sustainable economic growth in Turkmenistan and the 
development of an integrated and efficient railway system in the region. The project will reduce 
transport costs, cut travel times, and improve accessibility to rural areas of the country. This will 
generate benefits beyond savings in railway transport costs and time. Experience in Africa and 
Europe indicates that transit traffic is usually a lucrative business for railways, governments, and 
the  service  sector  (including  logistics).  Commercial  mineral  resources  in  areas  along  the 
alignment could be developed because of the heavy-haul capacity of the railway. The new line 
will  also  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the  Awaza  National  Tourism  Zone  Project3 in 
Turkmenistan by simplifying the transport of construction materials and logistics support.  
 
4.  Railway  sector.  Turkmenistan’s  railway  system  uses  the  1,520  millimeter  gauge 
common to the former Soviet railways. When Turkmenistan gained independence in 1991, the 
railway had 2,268 km of operational lines; in 2010 the system has 3,110 km. The principal 
routes  include  multiple  connections  with  neighboring  countries,  including  Afghanistan, 
Azerbaijan, Iran, and Uzbekistan. Rehabilitation of a railway line to northern Afghanistan is 
planned to begin in 2011. 
                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The planned north–south railway line has two parts: (i) the Uzen–Bereket line (596.0 km) in the north (466 km 
through Turkmenistan from Bereket to the Kazakhstan border and 130 km through Kazakhstan from its border to 
Uzen) to be financed by the governments of Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan for the sections located in their 
territories; and (ii) the Bereket–Atrek–Gorgan line (338.5 km) in the south from Bereket (256.5 km through 
Turkmenistan and 82.0 km through Iran) to be financed by the Islamic Development Bank.  
3  As per Turkmenistan presidential decree signed in October 2008, the Awaza National Tourism Zone Project is to 
be implemented by the Awaza National Project Committee.

2   
5.  The north–south railway line will reduce by about 680 km the distance for transportation 
of goods from Central Asia to the Persian Gulf ports, according to government data. The line is 
expected to become an important link in the transcontinental transport corridor. According to 
initial projections, about 3–4 million tons are expected to be transported on the line by 2015, and 
increasing to more than 13 million tons in 2020. 
 
6.  The railway plays a major role in transportation in Turkmenistan. In 2008, 25.4 million 
tons of freight was moved by rail, with an average length of haul of 454 km. While road transport 
moved  more  tonnage  (560.5  million  tons),  the  average  length  of  haul  was  only  17 km. 
Passenger transport shows similar results: 6.2 million rail passengers moved an average of 270 
km, while 1,065 million road passengers moved an average of 20 km.4 Because major cities are 
far apart, the long-haul capability of railways in intercity transport is an important contributor to 
Turkmenistan’s economy.  
 
7.  The Ministry of Railway Transport (MRT) owns, operates, and regulates the railway 
network. Although private freight forwarding companies exist, there are no plans to increase the 
role of the private sector in railway operations.   
 
8.  Railway sustainability. The network is being expanded along with recent and planned 
additions to the locomotive, coach, and freight wagon fleets. The fleets are well maintained and 
operate according to schedules. Reviews of budgets and expenditures indicate that the railway 
system  is  solvent  and  should  remain  so  given  the  rising  freight  volumes  and  revenues. 
Increasing transit traffic is a government priority, and the country is well placed to achieve this 
objective.  The  MRT  has  adequate  railway  maintenance  equipment.  However,  track 
maintenance and safety equipment will need to be procured for any new track development. 
The MRT also requires skills for modern scheduling of routine and periodic maintenance to 
improve locomotive utilization. Furthermore, the MRT needs training in implementing externally 
funded projects as the country plans to expand its transportation network through international 
assistance. 
 
9.  Relevance  and  strategic  alignment.  The  proposed  loan  will  be  ADB's  first  to 
Turkmenistan. A country partnership strategy is planned. The project is in line with the Transport 
and Trade Facilitation Strategy of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
program5 as it provides a key north–south link between two east–west CAREC corridors. The 
project is also aligned with ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative because the project railway 
will (i) be accessible, (ii) be safer than travel by road, (iii) produce less emissions per ton hauled 
than by road, and (iv) be more affordable than road transport. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the project will be increased trade between Turkmenistan and other 
countries in the region. The outcome will be better connectivity with neighboring countries and 
an efficient, safe, and reliable railway transport network in Turkmenistan. By utilizing rail instead 
of road to haul freight and passengers, air pollution will be reduced. 
 
                                                 
4  National Statistics Department. 2009. Statistics Yearbook of Turkmenistan, 2000–2008. Ashgabat. 
5  ADB. 2008. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy and Action Plan. Manila.

3
C.  Outputs 
11.  The outputs will be as follows6: 
(i)  Power, signaling, and telecommunication systems will be procured and installed 
for 311 km of the completed railway line between Bereket and Buzkhun. This 
section  does  not  involve  land  acquisition  or  involuntary  resettlement,  and 
significant  environmental  impacts  are  not  anticipated.  The  power  supply 
component covers design, supply, installation, and commissioning of two 10.0-
kilovolt  overhead  power  lines,  a  distribution  system,  substations,  and  a 
supervisory control and data acquisition  system. Training on the supervisory 
control and data acquisition system will also be provided under this component, 
including environmental mitigation as required. The signaling component covers 
design, installation, and commissioning of signaling equipment including training 
and environmental mitigation as required. The telecommunication component 
covers  the  supply,  installation,  and  commissioning  of  mobile  train  radio 
communication and a long distance telecommunication network, and training. 
(ii)  Equipment  procured  for  track  maintenance  and  safety  will  include  ballast 
cleaning and sand removal machines, hot box detectors, and train derailment 
sensors. These important train safety technologies, which have not been used in 
Turkmenistan, will lead to more capacity and more efficient train operations. 
(iii)  The institutional capacity of the MRT will be improved and project management 
support will be provided. The following outputs are envisaged:  
(a)  Locomotive  utilization  improvement  and  asset  management.  This 
subcomponent will focus on modern scheduling of routine and periodic 
maintenance to improve locomotive availability and reliability throughout 
the MRT network. An asset management system will be developed and 
staff will be trained to update and maintain the inventory of all MRT 
assets and asset utilization data annually. 
(b)  Environmental monitoring and management. This subcomponent will 
include  implementing  the  environmental  monitoring  and  management 
plan  for  the  project  following  ADB  guidelines,  but  will  also  focus  on 
establishing an environmental unit within the MRT. Staff will be trained 
and the MRT’s environmental policy and standard operating procedures 
will  be  prepared  in  conformity  with  government  regulations  and 
international practice. 
(c)  Procurement,  project  administration,  and  financial  management. 
Consulting  services  for  this  subcomponent  will  help  to  complete  the 
project in a timely manner, but will also support the MRT in developing 
greater  capacity  in  managing  loans  and  in  international  competitive 
bidding. This will focus on improving the MRT’s staff capacity in project 
management,  sound  financial  control,  design  confirmation, 
implementation  supervision  for  day-to-day  oversight  of  contractors’ 
progress, quality assurance, testing and commissioning of equipment, 
safeguards review, and timely reporting of progress to the government 
and ADB. These will become important assets as the country expands its 
transportation  network  through  international  assistance.  This 
subcomponent will also look into new railway financing modalities and the 
use of public–private initiatives.

3.  Loan Terms 
14.  Because of its internal administrative processes, the government has indicated a strong 
preference for a loan with the interest rate being fixed at loan signing. This would require certain 
changes to ADB's LIBOR-based loan product. To allow the government greater flexibility in 
choosing the loan product that best fits its needs, it is proposed to offer the government two 
options. Both options will provide loans with a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, 
and a commitment charge of 0.15% per year.7 
15.  The first option will be ADB’s standard OCR loan with an annual interest rate and other 
                                                 
7  ADB’s Ordinary Operations Loan Regulations Applicable to LIBOR-Based Loans Made from ADB's Ordinary

each respective loan agreement.

5
terms and conditions determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility. The 
second option will be a loan with an interest rate fixed at loan signing. The fixed-interest loan 
terms  will  follow  cost  pass-through  pricing,  which  is  the  principle  of  ADB's  asset–liability 
management policy.8 Pricing of the fixed-interest loan will include the standard contractual 
lending spread applicable to ADB's sovereign OCR loans, but the cost base rate will be based 
on ADB's cost of funding and/or hedging the fixed-rate loan, as well as other risk components 
related  to  fixed-interest  loans.  This  will  entail  certain  waivers  from  ADB’s  lending  policy,9 
including (i) the interest rate being fixed at loan signing; (ii) rebate and surcharge on funding 
cost margin not being applied; and (iii) a cancellation fee being charged to pass on any costs 
incurred as a result of rate-fixing. Before loan signing, the government will provide ADB with (a) 
the reasons for its decision to borrow on these terms and conditions, and (b) an undertaking that 
these  choices  were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any 
communication or advice from ADB. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The MRT will be the executing agency. Its Construction and Civil Structures Department, 
which has the mandate for all construction and procurement works of the MRT, will be the 
implementation agency. The MRT’s Power Supply and Communication Department, which is 
mainly  responsible  for  operation  and  maintenance  of  power  supply,  signaling  and 
telecommunication,  will  support  the  implementing  agency  and  coordinate  all  the  MRT 
departments. An international firm will be engaged as project management consultants. The 
project management consultants will manage contracts with the Construction and Civil Structures 
Department and the Power Supply and Communication Department, as well as provide hands-on 
training in project management and oversight, financial management, operation and maintenance, 
asset management, and reporting. As this will be ADB’s first project in Turkmenistan, the MRT’s 
related departments will improve their capacity to implement externally funded projects. Thus, the 
project will not include a conventional project management unit. Contracts will include premiums 
as  incentive  and  penalties  to  encourage  timely  completion  within  the  contract  period.  The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the project 
administration manual.10 
17.  The procurement of goods will be undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). International competitive bidding (ICB) will be 
used for goods contracts estimated to cost $1 million and above. National competitive bidding is 
not applicable. Three contract packages are proposed: package 1 (design, supply, and installation 
of power supply, signaling, and telecom) using the one stage–two envelope modality; package 2 
(supply of track machinery and supply and installation of safety equipment); and package 3 
(consulting services).  
18.  Consultants will be recruited according to ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). A total of 176 person-months of consulting services (64 
international, 112 national) grouped into one package will be funded under the project to support 
the MRT in (i) design review and implementation supervision; (ii) train operations management, 
(iii) environmental monitoring, (iv) procurement management, and (v) project implementation 
and institutional capacity improvement. Consultants will be engaged using quality- and cost-
based selection, with the standard ratio of 80:20.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
20.  Due diligence for the project included an assessment of the project investment plan, 
operational  cost  structure,  and  maintenance  requirements.  The  design  features  and 
construction standards of the completed 311 km of railway and its complementarities with the 
existing system were also reviewed.  
21.  The existing railway system has adequate capacity in terms of locomotive power, wagon 
availability for the expected commodities, line capacity, and a well-trained and experienced 
workforce. The selection of the main alignment of the railway was based on the shortest 
distance from the junction to the existing railway, and the efficiency of service for villages within 
the project area was emphasized. Impacts on land acquisition, involuntary resettlement, and 
arable agricultural lands were avoided. The MRT selected a track alignment that minimizes the 
effects of the barchans, which make construction and track maintenance difficult. The sand 
removal machines included in the project will ensure efficient removal of sand.  
22.  The  detailed  design  of  the  newly  laid  railway  line  and  its  safety  aspects  during 
construction, operation, and maintenance were reviewed. The railway line was built following 
international standards with state-of-the art components for track construction. Sub-grade and 
alignment were well designed and properly constructed. Materials, such as sleepers and rail, 
are  state-of-the-art  for  a  rail  line  that  will  carry  about  3  million–15  million  tons  annually. 
According to the Union Internationale des Chemins de Fer,11 this type of rail has an economic 
life corresponding to at least 800 million gross tons. Therefore, it will not need to be replaced for 
at least 50 years. The concrete sleepers will have a similar life. The signaling system and safety 
enhancement  devices  included  in  the  project  will  promote  safe  train  operations  after 
commissioning. The proposed electronic interlocking at stations and automatic signaling will 
provide  positive  train  separation.  The  mobile  train  radio  system  and  long  distance 
                                                 
11 Paris-based International railway union that sets and publishes railway material and design standards.

7
telecommunications  network  will  facilitate  efficient  railway  operations.  Other  state-of-the-art 
technologies to be applied under the project include (i) electronic interlocking, cab signaling, 
light-emitting diode-lit color light automatic signals directly controlled by audio frequency; and (ii) 
a long distance network based on optical fiber cables with synchronous transport modules 1 and 
16 equipment. Since electric power is only available at the existing Bereket station, the power 
supply network included in the project will provide reliable power for efficient train operations. 
Safety enhancement devices, including defective bearing detectors and dragging and derailed 
equipment detectors, are also included in the project to enhance operational safety. Collectively, 
the  items  included  in  project  will  support  safer  and  more  efficient  train  operations,  and 
significantly enhance the long-term capacity of the railway. 
23.  The  MRT's  staffing  capacity  for  railway  operation,  including  experience  in  sand 
operations  and  operating  rolling  stock  and  locomotives  to  handle  the  forecast  tonnage,  is 
adequate. The locomotive fleet has sufficient capacity to handle the incremental volume that is 
expected  on  the  new  line,  but  improvements  in  locomotive  productivity  are  required.  The 
institutional capacity improvement under the project will enhance the MRT’s management and 
implementation  capacity.  Traffic  forecasts  include  newly  generated,  road-diverted,  and  rail-
diverted freight and passenger traffic. Based on these forecasts, train operations within the 
established tonnage parameters are predicted. These volumes fit well within the design capacity 
of the new line, increasing to 22 trains per day by 2020. 
 
B.  Economic 
24.  The economic evaluation covered all the project components, including track machinery 
and fixtures, signaling, power supply, telecommunications, design review and implementation 
supervision, and capacity improvement.  In addition, the associated completed works on the 311 
km of the north–south railway, including track, stations and rolling stock, have been factored into 
the economic evaluation. Annual operating costs have also been included in the analysis. 
25.  Economic benefits include (i) user cost savings for freight and passenger traffic; (ii) time 
savings  for  diverted  passenger  and  freight  traffic  from  buses,  trucks,  and  other  rail  lines; 
(iii) benefits attributable to generated traffic; (iv) more tourism; (v) shipper savings because of 
increased  railway  competition;  (vi)  avoided  road  accidents;  (vii)  less  pollution;  (viii) energy 
savings; and (ix) higher national productivity. 
26.  The economic internal rate of return for the project is 16.65%. Benefits from freight 
traffic, including benefits attributable to generated traffic, are the major economic benefits, with 
passenger benefits  contributing  minimally,  and  other  benefits  making  up  the  balance.  The 
sensitivity analysis tested 10 scenarios to assess the robustness of the results of the economic 
analysis. The total cost would have to be more than 28.0% higher than estimated for the 
economic internal rate of return to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. A 1-year delay in completion 
would reduce the net present value by 52%. Combinations of adverse effects on benefits and 
costs were also tested. The results showed that the project would maintain its economic viability 
under plausible scenarios of variability in key parameters. 
C.  Financial 
27.  Financial sustainability for the project was assessed. The government has very low 
levels of debt, and its revenues and surpluses are increasing as more of the country’s gas fields 
are developed. The country has the world’s fourth-largest gas fields, which will be brought into

8   
production in the near future.12 The railway is sufficiently solvent to increase the length of its 
network, purchase additional new rolling stock, and upgrade its technologies. Importantly, the 
railway is strongly committed to maintenance, and maintenance schedules are fully followed. 
Costs have been reduced and train schedules are met with only a few service interruptions.  
28.  The project railway will be largely for freight and will attract considerable transit traffic.  
Freight tariffs are adequate to meet all project costs. Passenger tariffs are low and cross- 
subsidized  by  freight  revenues,  which  is  common  in  many  countries.  The  project  will  be 
sustainable and provide considerable benefits to the country and to the areas along the railway.  
 
D.  Governance 
29.  A governance assessment was undertaken as part of the due diligence process. This 
focused on the legal framework, regulation, strength of enforcement regimes, capacity of the 
MRT, human resources, and risk of corruption. 
30.  On 25 September 2008, Turkmenistan adopted a new Constitution, which gives the 
Parliament full legislative authority. The Parliament has the power to (i) pass laws; (ii) amend 
the Constitution; (iii) approve the state budget; (iv) set dates for the elections of the President, 
members of the legislature, and local governing bodies; and (v) ratify or reject international 
treaties.  Parliament  also  renders  binding  interpretations  of  laws  and  determines  the 
constitutionality of legal acts issued by the executive branch of government.  
31.  The  Law  of  Turkmenistan  on  Railway  Transport  (enacted  on  15  September  1998) 
designates the MRT to undertake all investments in infrastructure, rolling stock, and other fixed 
assets; and to operate freight and passenger trains on its tracks. MRT investments and tariffs 
are subject to the approval of the cabinet of ministers. The MRT does not receive a special 
subsidy from the government and is expected to cover its operating costs through freight and 
passenger revenues. A special budgetary appropriation is made to finance large infrastructure 
investments that aim to improve network capacity and the efficiency of operations.  
32.  The  country  has  established  adequate  budgetary  controls  and  oversight  to  ensure 
efficiency and accountability. The legal frameworks for managing public finances have been 
tightened. In line with this, the MRT has an accounting system that allows for the proper 
recording of financial transactions, including the allocation of expenditures to the respective 
components of development projects. The accounting system is available and interconnected 
with  the  State  Bank  for  Foreign  Economic  Affairs.  Controls  are  in  place  concerning  the 
preparation and approval of transactions, ensuring that all transactions are correctly made. The 
MRT has an internal audit department with qualified and experienced staff. The MRT financial 
statements are audited regularly by an independent auditor, the Supreme Chamber of Control.13 
33.  A major issue is the public procurement process and price verification for all foreign-
funded contracts and contract variations. All major contracts under the proposed project will be 
subjected to ICB and direct payment procedures. This increases oversight and helps mitigate 
corruption. The verification contributes to good governance, but sometimes creates project 
implementation delays. ADB and the government have agreed on actions to reduce these 
delays by sharing databases and other information on cost estimates and sources. The MRT

greater  institutional  capacity,  will  result  in  project  oversight,  ensuring  good  quality  in 
implementation, timely project completion, and compliance with ADB guidelines and policies.  
34.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the MRT. The project will have a strong internal and external auditing 
presence. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the 
project administration manual (footnote 10). 
 
E.  Poverty and Social 
35.  The project is not a targeted intervention. It does not address poverty reduction through 
standard direct actions at the level of households, or involve specific services that address the 
geographical determinants of poverty. The project will not exacerbate gender inequities.   
36.  About 3,200 people live in nine villages 3–10 km from the railway line. They are involved 
mainly  in  sheep  herding.  The  project  impact  area  is  arid  with  only  limited  water  sources. 
Summers and winters have extreme temperatures.   
37.  In addition to the train crews, the railway will employ about 175–200 people at 12 
stations on the line north of Bereket. About 100 of these positions will be filled by people from 
the local areas. Small shops and restaurants will also be set up at the new passenger and 
freight stations at nine locations.  
38.  While economic activity is currently limited in the project impact area, it contains mineral 
resources that could not be exploited before because of the lack of low-cost transport. The 
railway will enable the exploitation of these deposits, including coal, gold, kaolin, and platinum. 
Therefore, the project will generate additional jobs and improve mobility and access to health 
and other services for people living in the project impact area.   
F.  Safeguards 
39.  The project will not have any major environmental impacts. In line with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project  is  classified  as  environment  category  B.  An  initial 
environmental  examination  has  been  prepared  for  the  project  and  is  disclosed  on  ADB’s 
website. The investments will not result in regional or international environmental impacts. 
Installation of signaling and telecommunication under the project, and the completed 311 km of 
railway  track  under  government  financing,  does  not  involve  land  acquisition  or  involuntary 
resettlement,  or  affect  ethnic  minority  groups.  The  project’s  rights-of-way  were  established 
during the Soviet era, and the land use of the area has not changed since then. The project is 
classified as category C for both involuntary resettlement and indigenous people. A social 
safeguard diligence report was prepared during project preparation.14 
G.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
40.  Table 4 summarizes the major risks and mitigating measures, focusing mainly on the

has not administered projects funded by multilateral financing institutions. To mitigate this risk,

preparing ICB contract documents of goods in advance. To further support timely bid evaluation

IV.  ASSURANCES 
41.  The government and the MRT have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. The government and the MRT have 
agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement. 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$125,000,000 to Turkmenistan for the North–South Railway Project from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources, for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and 
 
(i)  with interest and such other terms and conditions to be determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate-based lending facility, or  
 
(ii)  with fixed interest and such other terms and conditions, including certain waivers 
from ADB’s lending policy, as described in paragraph 15 of this report.
